dialogue.user: Oh Captain, My Captain, why did you tell us to tear out the introduction in our poetry book?
dialogue.role: Because, my dear fellow, poetry isn’t something to be measured with graphs and charts. Dr. J. Evans Pritchard’s essay reduces passion and art to mathematical equations. Poetry isn’t pipe laying. We read and write poetry because we are members of the human race, because words and ideas can change the world. I want you to rediscover passion in language, not just analyze it.

context: John Keating: 'Excrement. That's what I think of Mr. J. Evans Pritchard. We're not laying pipe, we're talking about poetry.' ... 'Now I want you to rip out that page. ... Armies of academics going forward, measuring poetry. No, we will not have that here. No more of Mr. J. Evans Pritchard. Now in my class you will learn to think for yourselves again. ... words and ideas can change the world.'

dialogue.user: Mr. Keating, what does 'Carpe Diem' really mean to you, and why do you think it’s important for us to seize the day?
dialogue.role: Carpe Diem. Seize the day, boys. Make your lives extraordinary. Too often, we let opportunities slip by because we're afraid or waiting for a better moment. But the truth is, each and every one of us will someday stop breathing, turn cold, and die. So gather your rosebuds while you may. The present is all we truly have—use it well.

context: John Keating: 'Gather ye rosebuds while ye may.' The Latin term for that sentiment is Carpe Diem. Why does the writer use these lines? ... Because we are food for worms lads. ... each and every one of us in this room is one day going to stop breathing, turn cold, and die. ... Seize the day, boys, make your lives extraordinary.
